entry.title: The Non-Domestic Rating Contributions (Wales) (Amendment) Regulations 1995
The Insurance Companies (Overseas Life Assurance Business) (Tax Credit) Regulations 1995
The Cheese and Cream Regulations 1995
entry.summary: These Regulations supersede the Cheese Regulations 1970 (S.I. No. 94) and the Cream Regulations 1970 (S.I. No. 752) and their Scottish equivalents which are revoked by these Regulations.

entry.title: The City of Sunderland College (Incorporation) Order 1995
entry.summary: This Order establishes a further education corporation under section 16 (1) of the Further and Higher Education Act 1992 for the purpose of establishing and conducting City of Sunderland College and appoints 1st August 1996 as the “operative date” for the purposes of Part I of that Act.

entry.title: The Finance Act 1995, section 63 (2), (Appointed Day) Order 1995
The Health and Safety (Repeals and Revocations) Regulations 1995
The Docks and Harbours (Rateable Values) (Scotland) Amendment (No.2) Order 1995
The Jobseekers Act 1995 (Commencement No. 1) Order 1995
The Medicines (Sale or Supply) (Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Regulations 1995
The Deregulation (Building Societies) Order 1995
The Medicines (Products Other Than Veterinary Drugs) (General Sale List) Amendment Order 1995
The Insurance Companies (Gilt-edged Securities) (Periodic Accounting for Tax on Interest) Regulations 1995
entry.summary: Section 51A(1) of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 (“the 1988 Act”), inserted by section 77 of the Finance Act 1995 (“the 1995 Act”), provides that, in certain circumstances, interest on gilt-edged securities shall be paid without deduction of income tax and that the interest so paid shall be chargeable under Case III of Schedule D. Section 51B of the 1988 Act, inserted by section 78(1) of the 1995 Act, provides that the Treasury may by regulations provide that persons to whom payments of interest on gilt-edged securities are made without deduction of tax shall make periodic returns to an officer of the Commissioners of Inland Revenue. The powers conferred on the Treasury by section 51B of the 1988 Act were exercised in the Gilt-edged Securities (Periodic Accounting for Tax on Interest) Regulations 1995 (S.I. 1995/3224) (“the Gilts Regulations”). These Regulations make further provision in relation to companies carrying on life assurance business.

entry.title: The Water Undertakings (Rateable Values) (Scotland) (No.2) Order 1995
entry.summary: This Order makes provision for the valuation for financial years 1996-97 to 1999-2000 of certain lands and heritages occupied by water authorities and wholly or mainly used for the purposes of water undertakings carried on by them (“the prescribed class of lands and heritages”) (article 3).

entry.title: The City of Sunderland College (Government) Regulations 1995
entry.summary: These Regulations prescribe the form of instrument of government and articles of government for City of Sunderland College.

entry.title: The Gilt-edged Securities (Periodic Accounting for Tax on Interest) Regulations 1995
entry.summary: Section 51A(1) of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 (“the 1988 Act”), inserted by section 77 of the Finance Act 1995 (“the 1995 Act”), provides that, in certain circumstances, interest on gilt-edged securities shall be paid without deduction of income tax and that the interest so paid shall be chargeable under Case III of Schedule D. Section 51B of the 1988 Act, inserted by section 78(1) of the 1995 Act, provides that the Treasury may by regulations provide that persons to whom payments of interest on gilt-edged securities are made without deduction of tax (“gross payments”) shall make periodic returns to an officer of the Commissioners of Inland Revenue. These Regulations exercise the powers conferred on the Treasury by section 51B of the 1988 Act.

entry.title: The Lloyd’s Underwriters (Gilt-edged Securities) (Periodic Accounting for Tax on Interest) Regulations 1995
entry.summary: Section 51A(1) of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 (“the 1988 Act”), inserted by section 77 of the Finance Act 1995 (“the 1995 Act”), provides that, in certain circumstances, interest on gilt-edged securities shall be paid without deduction of income tax and that the interest so paid shall be chargeable under Case III of Schedule D. Section 51B of the 1988 Act, inserted by section 78(1) of the 1995 Act, provides that the Treasury may by regulations provide for persons to whom payments of interest on gilt-edged securities are made without deduction of tax to make periodic returns to an officer of the Commissioners of Inland Revenue. These Regulations exercise the powers conferred on the Treasury by section 51B of the 1988 Act in relation to Lloyd’s Underwriters.

entry.title: The Misuse of Drugs (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 1995
The South Wales Fire Services (Combination Scheme) Order 1995
entry.summary: This Order makes a scheme which combines the areas of the following new principal councils in South Wales, namely Blaenau Gwent County Borough Council, Bridgend County Borough Council, Caerphilly County Borough Council, Cardiff County Council, Merthyr Tydfil County Borough Council, Monmouthshire County Council, Newport County Borough Council, Rhondda Cynon Taff County Borough Council, Torfaen County Borough Council and the Vale of Glamorgan County Borough Council (which would otherwise become individual fire authorities on 1st April 1996 by virtue of the Local Government (Wales) Act 1994) into a combined fire area. The scheme comes into force on the same day as the Order comes into force for the purpose of doing anything which is necessary to bring the scheme fully into operation on 1st April 1996. The scheme establishes a fire authority for the combined area, to be known as the South Wales Fire Authority or Awdurdod Tân De Cymru, and provides for the appointment and terms of office of its members, and for meetings of the Authority. The scheme establishes a fire brigade for the combined area, to be known as the South Wales Fire Service or Gwasanaeth Tân De Cymru, appoints its first chief officer, and provides for the submission of an establishment scheme to the Secretary of State. The scheme establishes a combined fire service fund and provides for the administration of the Authority’s finances (including payment of compensation). The scheme also provides for the transfer of staff, and certain property, rights and liabilities from Mid Glamorgan, South Glamorgan and Gwent county councils (the fire authorities for the area prior to 1st April 1996) to the new combined authority.

entry.title: The Mid and West Wales Fire Services (Combination Scheme) Order 1995
entry.summary: This Order makes a Scheme which combines the areas of the following new principal councils in Mid and West Wales, namely Cardiganshire County Council, Carmarthenshire County Council, Neath and Port Talbot County Borough Council, Pembrokeshire County Council, Powys County Council and Swansea County Council (which would otherwise become individual fire authorities on 1st April 1996 by virtue of the Local Government (Wales) Act 1994) into a combined fire area. The scheme comes into force on the same day as the Order comes into force for the purpose of doing anything which is necessary to bring the scheme fully into operation on 1st April 1996. The scheme establishes a fire authority for the combined area, to be known as the Mid and West Wales Fire Authority or Awdurdod Tân Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru, and provides for the appointment and terms of office of its members, and for meetings of the Authority. The scheme establishes a fire brigade for the combined area, to be known as the Mid and West Wales Fire Brigade or Brigâd Dân Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru, appoints its first chief officer, and provides for the submission of an establishment scheme to the Secretary of State. The scheme establishes a combined fire service fund and provides for the administration of the Authority’s finances (including payment of compensation). The scheme also provides for the transfer of staff, and certain property, rights and liabilities from Dyfed, Powys and West Glamorgan county councils (the fire authorities for the area prior to 1st April 1996) to the new combined authority.

entry.title: The North Wales Fire Services (Combination Scheme) Order 1995
entry.summary: This Order makes a scheme which combines the areas of the following new principal councils in North Wales, namely Aberconwy and Colwyn County Borough Council, Anglesey County Council, Caernarfonshire and Merionethshire County Council, Denbighshire County Council, Flintshire County Council and Wrexham County Borough Council (which would otherwise become individual fire authorities on 1st April 1996 by virtue of the Local Government (Wales) Act 1994), into a combined fire area. The scheme comes into force on the same day as the Order comes into force for the purpose of doing anything which is necessary to bring the scheme fully into operation on 1st April 1996. The scheme establishes a fire authority for the combined area, to be known as the North Wales Fire Authority or Awdurdod Tân Gogledd Cymru and provides for the appointment and terms of office of its members, and for meetings of the Authority. The scheme establishes a fire brigade for the combined area, to be known as the North Wales Fire Service or Gwasanaeth Tân Gogledd Cymru, appoints its first chief officer, and provides for the submission of an establishment scheme to the Secretary of State. The scheme establishes a combined fire service fund and provides for the administration of the Authority’s finances (including payment of compensation). The scheme also provides for the transfer of staff, and certain property, rights and liabilities, directly from Clwyd and Gwynedd county councils (the fire authorities for the area prior to 1st April 1996) to the new combined authority.
